medical_history.chief_complaint: Newly diagnosed disseminated tuberculosis (TB) affecting lungs and multiple lymph nodes, including mesenteric lymph nodes.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The current TB condition started 6 weeks before referral. The patient presented with high-grade fever, mainly at night with sweating, severe abdominal pain, significant weight loss, and fatigability. Two weeks later, he developed a cough, which was initially dry and then became productive with thick mucoid sputum without blood.
medical_history.past_medical_history: The patient has a history of two episodes of mycobacterial lymphadenitis and recurrent typhoid fever. He had fever and left axillary lymphadenitis at 6 months of age, which did not improve with antibiotics. At 2 years, he experienced fever, weight loss, and cervical lymphadenopathy along with recurrent febrile illnesses associated with abdominal pain and mesenteric lymphadenitis.
medical_history.family_history: Four other family members across two generations have a similar condition, including the father who had recurrent TB adenitis since early childhood, confirmed tuberculous meningitis, and Aspergillus meningitis. A maternal cousin had disseminated BCG infection leading to early infantile death. Positive family history of recurrent adenitis among paternal relatives.
